Meredith J. Durbin

Research and Instrument Analyst, STScI

Hubble WFC3 team

My Work

WFC3

  • Currently working on updating the WFC3/IR bad pixel table
  • Built web interface to query MySQL database of >170,000 WFC3 in-flight images
  • PI of Cycle 23 calibration programs 14367 (UVIS bowtie monitor) and 14374 (IR dark monitor)
  • Created HST photometric conversion web tool
  • Published Instrument Science Reports:
    • ISR 2015-06: The Impact of Blobs on WFC3/IR Stellar Photometry. M. J. Durbin, P. R. McCullough. 28 April 2015
    • ISR 2015-01: IR “Snowballs”: Long-Term Characterization. M. J. Durbin, M. Bourque, S. Baggett. 10 March 2015

CANDELS

I have been working with Dr. Henry Ferguson on the CANDELS collaboration since June 2015 doing completeness testing on the GOODS fields in F160W. To do this, we insert simulated galaxies into subsets of the GOODS fields chosen for uniform depth. By examining how many artificial galaxies at a given magnitude and radius can be recovered by SExtractor we can characterize the limiting surface brightness by field depth for GOODS F160W, and by comparing the input vs. observed magnitudes and radii we can characterize the accuracy of our photometry catalogs.

Past Work

I graduated from Pomona College in May 2014 with a BA in astrophysics. My senior thesis was on the RR Lyrae period-luminosity relation in IRAC channels 1 and 2, supervised by Dr. Victoria Scowcroft at Carnegie Observatories and Dr. Alma Zook at Pomona. This work was presented as a poster at AAS224, and we are currently preparing it for publication; in the meantime, my thesis is available here, or you can read the condensed version on Astrobites.

In summer 2012 I worked with Dr. Alma Zook using the 1-meter telescope at JPL's Table Mountain Observatory to obtain optical blazar polarimetry data and characterize the telescope polarimeter; the results of this research were presented at AAS221.

I have a strong interest in diversity in the sciences; as an undergraduate I co-founded αLPhA ("Awesome Ladies in Physics and Astronomy") at Pomona College along with two other physics majors in the class of 2014. I'm also interested in science illustration and communication; I contributed several art pieces and designed publicity posters for Pomona's festival celebrating physics in the arts, PhysPhest, for two years.

On the right: me in front of my AAS225 poster.
